<TextBlock id="txt_spoke_agriculture" role="spoke" optional="false"> <Heading>Agriculture</Heading> <Body>Wheeled carts let farmers haul bigger harvests and heavier tools, boosting food production and fueling growing settlements.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_spoke_trade" role="spoke" optional="false"> <Heading>Trade</Heading> <Body>The wheel bridged distant towns, speeding up travel and helping markets thrive—turning Europe’s back roads into trade routes.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_spoke_warfare" role="spoke" optional="false"> <Heading>Warfare</Heading> <Body>Spoked wheels on chariots brought swift, mobile combat; prestige and power followed wherever horse-drawn forces appeared.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_spoke_urbanization" role="spoke" optional="false"> <Heading>Urbanization</Heading> <Body>Carts carried stone and lumber to new heights, enabling bigger, denser cities to spring up across the European landscape.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_spoke_social_stratification" role="spoke" optional="false"> <Heading>Social Stratification</Heading> <Body>Owning a fine chariot or cart showed off wealth and influence, widening the gap between rich and poor.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_spoke_cultural_exchange" role="spoke" optional="false"> <Heading>Cultural Exchange</Heading> <Body>As carts rolled farther than ever before, ideas, goods, and customs spread along every path, weaving distant cultures together.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_spoke_technological_legacy" role="spoke" optional="false"> <Heading>Technological Legacy</Heading> <Body>From water mills to modern engines, the basic wheel-and-axle sparked centuries of invention—proof that simple machines can reshape civilization.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_callout_simple_machines" role="callout" optional="true"> <Heading>Simple Machines</Heading> <Body>Levers, pulleys, and wheels formed Europe’s earliest engineering toolkit, paving the way for future mechanical leaps and the Industrial Revolution.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_callout_domestication_of_horses" role="callout" optional="false"> <Heading>Domestication of Horses</Heading> <Body>Tamed on the Eurasian steppe over 5,000 years ago, horses gave people new speed and stamina—pulling carts, carrying riders, and turning the wheel from simple tool into an engine of exploration and power.</Body> <Source>Europe CI text.docx</Source> </TextBlock> <TextBlock id="txt_callout_before_after" role="callout" optional="false"> <Heading>Before & After the Wheel</Heading> <Body>Before: Sledges and human Using the metaphor of a wheel with spokes, the display highlights the transformative impacts of this innovation across different aspects of society, from agriculture to trade and warfare. The exhibit will visually represent these “spokes of change” radiating from the central invention of the wheel, illustrating how simple tools can have far-reaching consequences. While additional simple machines like levers and pulleys can be included as side notes, they should remain supplementary, emphasizing their connection to the broader theme of innovation. This optional section could hint at future expansions related to the Industrial Revolution.</DesignObjectivesAndSummary> <KeyDesignObjectives> <Block label="Hero Imagery"> <Line>A Cucuteni-Trypillia label="Functionality"> <Line>The wheel and axle combined to reduce friction, making it easier to move heavy loads.</Line> <Line>It became a versatile tool for work, travel, and innovation.</Line>
